content:
Hi!

This is quite a naive post. I'm interested in knowing more about automated theorem proving (both fully automated and computer-aided proving), and I wonder:

  1. What are some of the most reputable conferences?
  2. I guess most preprints are on arXiv, but are there good journals that provide a suitable filter?
  3. Which books are considered classic and must-read?
  4. In the US, what are some of the best grad schools in this field?

Thank you!

I cannot answer for the broader academic community.
For the kind of proving that we do here, I'd answer the following:
(1) ITP and CPP
https://itp-conference.github.io/
https://popl24.sigplan.org/home/CPP-2024
(2) JAR
https://link.springer.com/journal/10817
(3) Theorem Proving in Lean
#tpil
(4) I have no idea. I guess the best school is where @Mario Carneiro is.
https://www.cmu.edu/hoskinson/people/mario-carneiro.html

For automated reasoning (which I only dabble in), look at the CAV and IJCAR conferences and the Handbook of Automated Reasoning.

For interactive theorem proving with a focus on software verification (which, until recently, was almost the only kind of interactive theorem proving), the classic textbook/tutorial is Software Foundations. There's also a lot of software verification stuff at the big programming language conferences, POPL and PLDI. Excellent groups in the US include, off the top of my hat, those of Andrew Appel, Adam Chlipala, Benjamin Pierce, Stephanie Weirich, Steve Zdancewic and of course our Jeremy Avigad, but there are a lot more.

Wonderful, thank you guys!
Do you know any reputable research groups doing both automated reasoning and (theoretical) quantum computing? I'm interested in both :D

I am not sure anyone has mentioned this to you or not but there is the Zulip stream:

https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/219941-Machine-Learning-for-Theorem-Proving

which may be of interest to you. You will need to subscribe to it though as it is not a default stream.

Interesting. Subscribed!
Yea, I heard about AlphaGeometry, and found it intriguing!

For quantum computing, a good starting point is Verified Quantum Computing which is modeled after Software foundations. For much more past that, see https://github.com/inQWIRE. (Those sugestions are both in Coq, not sure about Lean)
